+Liam shaw
Okay......assuming you're British I'm going to allow the ignorance on the 
insight you have to OUR 2nd Amendment.

1.) The words "well regulated" in the 2nd Amendment are referencing the 
militias themselves, NOT firearms since gun registration is a 20th Century 
idea in the United States. Well regulated meaning by the states in order to 
defend themselves due to a lack of soldiers in the Army after the 
Revolutionary War. The United States knew that they did not have enough 
money, men, or supplies so militias were a necessity. If you read the 
Federalist Papers you would see that the requirements for militias was all 
males aged 14-40. They were to have a rifle and enough rations in case 
called to duty. This is also because of the laws for government which did 
not allow standing armies for more than two years when not at war.

2.) Your hilarious claim of the inventions that have occurred in firearms 
would make the 2nd Amendment null and void is fucking priceless!!! Rifling 
in barrels was invented in the mid 1500's so there goes that farce. Even 
still, there is NO mention of what types of guns are to be allowed or even 
not allowed. It plainly says "Arms" which is in obvious reference to 
firearms in general. The Founding Fathers were very precise in the writing 
of the Constitution and if you need a reference of that you should read 
about what Thomas Jefferson said on the clarity in which it was penned. You 
should also look into the rules that are placed on the Federal Government 
in the beginning that state that the Military is not allowed to posses any 
form of weapon that cannot be equally possessed by the citizenry. This is 
due to the fear of EXACTLY what is trying to be done now in the United 
States.

+iloveNgany
The 1689 Bill of Rights did not create a new right to have arms but instead 
rescinded and deplored acts of the deposed Catholic King James II, who, as 
far as relevant here, forced the disarming of Protestants while extending 
the right to bear arms to Catholics and Protestant dissenters in addition 
to upholding prior legislation that limited the ownership of arms to 
certain social classes.

The remedy in the 1689 Bill of Rights 2nd Amendment reads:
That the Subjects which are Protestants may have Arms for their Defence *suitable 
to their Conditions* and *as allowed by Law.*

The term "well regulated" would apply to any law of ownership, you are not 
born with gun and it wouldn't do much to stop a drone or missile shot from 
the other side of the country, it is essence written when the only arms 
available were muskets, if you did not adapt those guns to modern 
equivalent you would have 5 bullets, and gun powders separate to manually 
load each shot, in a non-rifled barrel with limited accuracy.

Obviously your rights can't trump laws enforced by the highest courts, so 
it would be dumb to imply popular majority could overrule law in any 
scenario.  Governments have evolved to the point that the purpose of the 
constitution; To prevent government from being too big, and prevent 
unnecessary war without any evidence of an imminent attack on the country, 
that they can no longer be contained by the constitution in many ways.

Is it assholes like this that make it so damn hard to buy guns in 
California? I mean I live in a state with no open carry, conceal and carry 
is only valid for the county you reside in and is almost impossible to get, 
and all the bullsh*t just to put a gun in my hands. I moved from a state 
with open carry, conceal and carry was just as easy as getting your driving 
or hunting license, there was a 24 or 48 hour wait period, and the 
background check consisted of calling the police station and asking if the 
buyer has a record. I honestly think we are too strict on gun laws.
Making guns harder to access for those getting them legally only makes it 
harder for law abiding citizens to protect themselves. There are large 
numbers of crimes committed with guns either stolen or acquired illegally. 
There are crimes where people use their legally owned guns, but these are 
frequently cases where someone is mentally unstable. The focus needs to not 
be on banning guns, but making gun safety well known. 
A good place to start is by having mandatory gun safety classes. That 
emphasize safe gun use, and appropriate situations to use a gun. Like not 
using a gun to hurt someone no matter how mad you are. 
Another good place to start is more cultural but changing censorship. A 
movie usually is not rated PG or PG-13 if it has graphic violence or gore. 
This shows that violent acts can be committed without any realistic 
consequences, and anyone that is impressionable from such influences will 
see violence as something that holds little consequence.
The most important area to start is mental health. Culturally we need to 
make mental health important and acceptable, and not degrade people or make 
them feel lesser for having a mental illness. If we could make mental 
health care readily available and teach people how to recognize when they 
need help, we could reduce crime further.﻿

Thank god I don't live in California.  Freedom comes at great cost - 
sometimes that cost is too great for some the bear.  The truth is, free 
people must have the right to arm themselves if they choose to do so.  All 
our rights in the United States, the first through the 27th, are upheld by 
private gun ownership and my argument can be summed up by going back in 
history and tracing the path to power of one person.  Hitler started the 
late 1920's as an out-of-work world war one veteran, failed artist and 
government stooge who was paid to spy on the National Socialist Workers 
Party. 

He choose to embrace their ideology and steadily rose through their ranks 
as he recruited more and more people to his political message: Germany had 
lost the "great war" because it's people had been "stabbed in the back" by 
the Jews.  In 1929, the Nazi party had less than 10 members in the elected 
government.  By January 30th, 1933, Hitler had been appointed Chancellor of 
Germany - a country of roughly 23 million people.  Despite the fact that 
Germany was very modern and even liberal for it's time - Hitler's regime 
slowly stripped the people of their ability to resist or even cooperate in 
their own Government. 

He abolished labor unions, competing political parties and even imprisoned 
political enemies in what was to become a network of concentration camps.  
The German people of the day thought they had "rights" and freedom.  Hitler 
swept aside laws he didn't want to abide by, he bullied, bribed or killed 
those who stood in his way and the German people went along with it.  Why?  
Because there was no viable way to fight back - the machinery of resistance 
had been legislated out of existence.  If you were to, say, protest someone 
like Adolf Hitler - you'd actually be doing some one like him a favor 
because he would simply surround the area with armed guards and arrest 
everybody (shooting anyone who resisted).  By demonstrating, you'd just be 
providing him with a very tempting target of political enemies who'd 
gathered themselves all at one point...

I think you people get the idea.  The second amendment is a guarantee of 
sorts for our rights.  It's the ultimate (and final, only last resort) 
check and balance on government by the people in the case that a tyrant 
rises to power.  I mean think about it - what if a political leader was 
elected to power and that person dismissed congress, the supreme court and 
any other legal safeguard against dictatorship.  What if we had another 
Caesar come to power who simply rode roughshod over all the laws and rights 
we thought protected us from such a situation?  Say massive amounts of 
people rose up to protest him and he ordered the military to strike the 10 
largest demonstrations with cluster bombs and AC-130 air-strikes?  How 
could the people respond to these actions?  With further demonstrations and 
protests?  The German people tried that and their "leaders" ended up 
starving to death in a concentration camp while Hitler embroiled the world 
into the most destructive conflict ever know to man.

Think about it - in 1937, if the Jews or the communists of Germany had the 
"right" to own and bear private firearms - Hitler would have faced a very 
different situation and had much greater obstacles to his rise to ultimate 
power.  Had the minority parties possessed firearms, Hitler's stormtroopers 
couldn't have hoped to be so bold as to march into neighborhoods, throw 
people out of their own homes and march them to the trains - the Jewish 
uprising in the Warsaw Ghetto or the Jewish rebellion in Belorussia (which 
started out with just a pistol and 6 rounds of ammunition) prove that.  
Private ownership of firearms could have stopped the second world war - it 
could have prevented someone like Adolf Hitler from having the position to 
invade Poland, France and Russia in 1941. 

This right, speaking exclusively to the second amendment, is the ultimate 
insurance against the collapse of law and order.  It represents the bulwark 
against which we can build a nation of laws within a government the people 
- instead of a king or a dictator - control.  Gun control - while well 
intentioned - ebbs that protection.  It slowly erodes the only shield the 
people really have against tyranny and autocratic rule.  Some may say that 
human nature has better angles of our nature - like our logic or our ethics 
and philosophy.  These contribute to society in meaningful ways but the 
German people of the 1930's had these same Western impulses and look at 
what happened.  Lastly - look at the realities of the modern world. 

All power descends from the ability to use force upon another.  If I am 
wrong about this - then why does the United States of America stand up a 
rocket force of 500 ICBM's, 18 Ohio-class Ballistic submarines and 
literally hundreds of long-range bombers (the so-called nuclear triad) 
capable of nuclear strikes on countries half way around the world?  Why was 
it that the Soviet Union never went to war with America during the cold war 
period?  One single over-ridding reason is deterrence or mutually assured 
destruction (M.A.D.).  The reason why we never attacked the Soviet Union 
(or why they never attacked us) was the fact that their (or our) response 
would be so devastating that a nuclear strike - by any side - was 
tantamount to suicide.  Enough warheads would get through that enough 
people would be killed, enough territory made unusable and enough 
infrastructure would be destroyed that mankind would effectively be thrown 
back to the stone age - if we survived at all.

M.A.D., and the systems that support it, might seem like a relic of a 
latter time - like the second amendment - but it has kept the peace between 
two super-powers during times of war.  M.A.D. has it's place in our 
national defense because the grotesqueness of our human nature do not allow 
for the alternative.  Much the same, the Second Amendment is the American 
people's "nuclear triad" - the government must always consider an armed 
rebellion if it tries to step outside the rule of law.  I understand the 
anguish of mother's who have lost their children to gang violence or people 
who have been wounded in a mass-shooting incident.  They have had a pile of 
rocks dropped upon them and it's so much easier to blame a object instead 
of confront the complexities of the social issues of our time.  I prey and 
hope for their lost and loved the way I do for their continued defeat at 
the political level when it comes to this issue.

In the end, a gun is a tool - much the same way a power drill can be 
misused to torture some one or build that same person a house to raise 
their children in.  I own many firearms like I do tools because they have 
their uses.  I look to support my country, the Constitution I swore to 
uphold when I joined the Army, my community and my family.  I stand to 
defend these interests in the off chance that the government is unable to 
do it (see Hurricane Katrina and the events in New Orleans), thus my 
ownership of firearms also stands as a bulwark against anarchism and 
opportunistic criminality during a national/regional disaster.  For these 
reasons, I own many firearms and a ready stock of ammunition and I see this 
as a patriotic tradition and duty that I take very seriously.  ﻿

firearm which means it requires a background check. And while you can 
easily "buy" them online, the real problem is retrieving it after it's been 
bought. The lower would have to be shipped to an FFL dealer before you can 
take possession of it. That FFL would have you fill out a 4473 to show 
disposition of the lower receiver and then run a background check on you 
via NICS. If you fail the background check, the FFL would not allow you to 
take possession of the receiver.﻿

+CarpathianCarl . I also discovered that you could use wooden Q-tips (they 
were more like cotton tipped swabs and were nearly 6" long IIRC). I 
wouldn't even wrap them with tape, just stick cotton end in first, pump 
like mad, then fire. It'd penetrate a phone book and lodge in w/o blowing 
apart. Really something. Similar to how a tornado can lodge a playing card 
into a wooden wall w/o the paper deforming.

+James M When I was 16, my dad bought me a Crosman 1377 BB gun. It was one 
of their single-shot pump BB guns with something like a 10" barrel. (.177 
cal; they made a .22 cal of the same design but never tested that). 
Anyways, I took a 2 liter bottle, (IIRC I cut the very bottom out for 
access) and stuck a small tube down the middle, then PACKED all around that 
with toilet paper (crumpled like paper or something along these lines). 
Once the bottle was packed , I removed the tube from the center. The bottle 
opening where the cap sits was reworked slightly to be able to sit over the 
barrel end. I'd pump 20x (more than recommended and louder) and it'd 
silence it almost completely. Foam (like the coned ends type) would 
probably work better as well fitting the inside walls easier. Leave the 
flat edge up against the inner wall, with the cone "fingers" facing inward. 
This should quiet down ANY air device rather easily. Can also use smaller 
plastic bottles, but the foam would need trimmed. With that same BB gun, 
I'd take a straight section of metal coat hanger (about 4" long) and file a 
perfect point on one end, while filing a perfectly FLAT end over the cut, 
and carefully wrap the rear, and a few inches back from the tip (so it 
could penetrate) with clear packing tape. The kind you use for Christmas 
presents that's narrow (like a 1/2" wide), and NOT the glossy version 
though it might work. Then I'd use 3-in-1 oil and put a few drops in the 
barrel as well as on the tape. Basically, the tape acts as a buffer between 
the rod and barrel surface with the oil reducing friction as well as 
creating a seal. Use scissors for the tape cuts to avoid the jagged edges. 
Use more tape than needed, then remove small sections until there's a few 
thousandths of clearance between the rolled section and barrel. This thing 
was MEAN and could penetrate a phone book further than a BB or pellet 
could. It could also poke through 16 gauge metal, though it'll ruin the 
front tape seal. If you shoot wooden surfaces, it can be reused 
indefinitely. Needs to be a *pump* BB gun with *long barrel* for best 
results. CO2 cartridge probably won't be strong enough.

+Eneko Zubizarreta Actually, The M-1 Garand clip has its origins in the 
Mannlicher clip, developed in Austria, for the Mannlicher bolt action 
rifle, and it's derivatives, the Italian Carcano; and the French Berthier. 
Both weapons used the Mannlicher clip, while the rest of the military 
rifles of the 19th century, adopted the clip (Mauser; Arisaka; Lee-Enfield 
and Mosin-Nagant.) This weapons had the ability to expel the clips out of 
the magazine box, below. The M-1 Garand clip was intended to be expelled 
out of the receiver, once it fired all its rounds, but it left behind a 
"clanky" noise, that it can be heard, if close enough. John C. Garand knew 
that this was a flaw, and wanted to make his rifle, magazine fed. 
Prototypes were developed during WW II, but they were bulky, and heavy, due 
to the modifications made to those prototypes (enlargement of the receiver 
and the use of the BAR magazine). Only with the adoption of the 7.62x51mm 
NATO, it was possible to adapt the action of the M-1 Garand and its 
original receiver, to adapt this cartridge. The result was the M-14 and the 
Beretta BM-59, an Italian Garand. Semi-auto weapons developed and used in 
WW II and, after, such as the Tokarev SVT-40; the G-43; the FN-49; and 
Ljungman AG-42/Hakim used the Mauser clip, to load into their magazines 
without trouble. Even the Japanese military developed a copy of the Garand 
that eliminated the clip in favor of a Mauser type stripper loader for its 
fixed 10 round magazine.

History could have been different if Garand adopted a stripper loader for 
its rifle, with an external 10-round magazine, like the Springfield rifle 
clip, which is basically a Mauser type rifle clip.
